text.p: The following are the main stories from Thursday morning's Austrian newspapers.

- Rumours of a possible government reshuffle are rife within the ruling Social Democrat Party, after it suffered heavy losses in the October 13 European Parliamentary elections. A closed party meeting on November 5 is seen as crucial.
- Austria's electronics industry, due to undergo hefty restructuring over the next few years, is pinning its hopes on new technical innovations to boost the stagnating market.
- Four in five Austrians are consciously aware of their nationality compared with less than half the population only 30 years ago.

- In Vienna 33 percent of inhabitants still support the current coalition between Social Democrats (SPOe) and the Conservative People's Party, despite the SPOe's loss of its absolute majority in the October 13 municipal elections.
- Builder Universale made a pre-tax profit of 10 million schillings in the first half of 1996, after losses of 56 million schillings the year before.
- In December the Finance Ministry plans to present its preliminary decisions on the privatisation of Creditanstalt.
- Post & Telekom Austria's subsidiary Mobilkom, poised to become an independent cost centre on November 1, is planning to invest three billion schillings in upgrading its GSM-network.
- Carton maker Mayr-Melnhof plans to cut jobs in Vienna as a result of a merger of its subsidiaries.
- Fire-proof material maker Radex-Heraklith's pre-tax profit rose seven percent in the first nine months.
- Austrians spent about seven billion schillings on shopping abroad in August alone.
- State-owned Post's Financial Chief Johannes Ditz is sceptical Post & Telekom Austria will reach its target of going public by 1999.
- The mad cow disease, BSE, has resulted in losses of around one billion schillings for Austrian farmers.
